name: Nurse Incident Report - Infusion Pump Occlusion Alarm Delay
description: Clinical staff submitting incident report about infusion pump alarm delay. Hospital incident report style with clinical details.

headers.subject: Incident Report - InfuSafe 4000 Pump Alarm Failure - IR#2024-0892

raw_input.body:
To: InfusionMed Device Complaints
From: Amanda Patel, RN, BSN - ICU Charge Nurse
Date: April 22, 2024
Re: Device Incident Report - Internal Reference IR#2024-0892

---

PATIENT INFORMATION:
Age: 67 | Sex: Female | Unit: Medical ICU | Room: MICU-12
Admission Diagnosis: Sepsis secondary to UTI

DEVICE INFORMATION:
Device: InfuSafe 4000 Infusion Pump
Serial Number: IF4K-2022-98234
Software Version: 4.2.1
Pump Channel: A

MEDICATION:
Norepinephrine 8 mcg/min via central line (right IJ)

INCIDENT DESCRIPTION:
Date/Time of Incident: April 21, 2024, 0345 hours

During routine assessment, I noticed patient's MAP had dropped from 72 to 58 mmHg over approximately 20 minutes. Upon investigation, I found the IV tubing was kinked at the pump loading area, causing a complete occlusion.

The pump did NOT alarm for occlusion. The infusion history showed the pump had detected "high pressure" at 0323 but continued to show "Infusing" status. No audible or visual alarm was generated.

The patient's blood pressure continued to decline for ~20 minutes until I identified the problem during rounds. Norepinephrine was restarted after unkinking the line and patient required a transient increase in dose (to 12 mcg/min) to restore hemodynamic stability.

PATIENT OUTCOME:
Patient experienced transient hypotension (MAP 55-58 x 20 min) requiring increased vasopressor support. Stabilized without further intervention. No lasting harm identified at this time.

ACTION TAKEN:
1. IV tubing repositioned and infusion restarted
2. Pump taken out of service and labeled
3. Incident report filed (IR#2024-0892)
4. Biomedical engineering notified
5. Manufacturer notification (this email)

OTHER PUMPS AFFECTED:
We have 24 InfuSafe 4000 pumps on this unit. Biomedical is checking all units for software version and alarm function testing.

PLEASE ADVISE:
- Is this a known issue with software version 4.2.1?
- Should we take any additional precautions?
- Will you be sending a field service representative?

Amanda Patel, RN, BSN
Charge Nurse, Medical ICU
St. Mary's Hospital
Direct: (555) 234-5678 ext 4512

cc: Risk Management, Pharmacy

event_info.event_description: Infusion pump failed to generate occlusion alarm despite detecting high pressure. Pump showed 'Infusing' status while tubing was kinked and medication (norepinephrine) was not being delivered. Alarm failure allowed patient's blood pressure to decline for approximately 20 minutes before issue was identified during rounds.
event_info.patient_outcome: Transient hypotension (MAP 55-58 mmHg for 20 minutes), required increased vasopressor dose, stabilized without lasting harm
event_info.device_outcome: Pump taken out of service, labeled, biomedical engineering notified

expected_complaint.narrative: Infusion pump failed to alarm for occlusion. During routine assessment, nurse noticed patient's MAP had dropped from 72 to 58 mmHg. IV tubing was found kinked at pump loading area. Pump detected high pressure at 0323 but continued showing 'Infusing' status with no alarm. Patient on norepinephrine drip experienced 20 minutes of hypotension before issue identified. Required increased vasopressor dose to stabilize. Pump software version 4.2.1, serial number IF4K-2022-98234.

ground_truth.coding_rationale: A11/A1101 (Software Problem/Application Program Problem) for alarm failure. A02 (Device Operates Differently Than Expected) as pump showed infusing when occluded. C0504 (Hypotension) for patient outcome. MDR required - infusion pump alarm failure could cause serious injury or death if vasopressor interruption goes undetected.

extraction_challenges: Software version potentially relevant to issue
Hospital incident report format with multiple sections
notes: Well-documented clinical incident. Nurse provides excellent detail. Software version noted - potential systematic issue. Hospital already initiated internal investigation.
